Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Vector and Tensor Field Design for Graphics and Visualization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Vector and tensor fields are fundamental in many science and engineering disciplines. This research explores the design and control of time-dependent vector and tensor fields over deformable domains, which have the potential of benefiting a wide variety of applications within and outside computer graphics and scientific
visualization. These applications include: weather prediction and tsunami simulation, building and aircraft design and testing, electromagnetic simulation, fingerprint analysis, special effects for movies and games, computer-generated arts, shape and motion analysis and editing, and education.

In this project, the investigator identifies core functionalities and develops efficient algorithms to support the design and control of time-dependent vector and tensor fields on time-dependent domains. Common design operations are identified by using a number of graphics and visualization tasks as a testbed, such as vector field visualization and fluid simulation. Efficient algorithms are provided for tracking and controlling structural changes in a vector or tensor field over time which enable control over the topology and analytical behaviors of the field. The ideas behind these algorithms are based on the concepts of fiber bundles and bifurcations from differential geometry and dynamic systems, respectively. In addition, the investigator explores novel visualization techniques to address time-dependent vector and tensor fields over deformable domains. As a result of the research, core design operations are integrated into a system, and implementations of these algorithms are compiled into libraries to support direct integration into host applications. Both the design system and its supporting libraries will be disseminated to the public. With respect to its impacts on
education, the design system is integrated into the curriculum forundergraduate students majoring in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vector and tensor fields are concepts from mathematics and physics that have found many applications in art, science, engineering, and medicine. The funded research is on the design of vector and tensor fields for scientific visualization and computer graphics.

Several research areas are explored, from which both theoretical and empirical discoveries have resulted.

The principal investigator (PI) and his collaborators have made much progress on vector field visualization, based on the notion of topology which is relatively new in scientific visualization. The researchers have identified two limitations with existing visualization techniques based on vector field topology, i.e., completeness, and robustness. Existing visualization techniques cannot extract all of periodic orbits in the vector field, nor can they be used to simplify a vector field that contains periodic orbits. The PI and his collaborators introduce a graph-based representation for vector fields that contain periodic orbits and provide algorithms to identify these periodic orbits as well as their connections to other constituents of topology, thus making vector field topology more complete, and vector field simplification possible. In a separate effort, the PI and his collaborators have recognized the uncertainty in vector field topology, as defined in traditional ways. They borrow modern results from dynamical systems, such as Conley index theory, to provide robust methods to deal with the uncertainty in the vector field. A hierarchal framework is later introduced to speed up the computation of the Conley index and Morse decomposition, both at the core of Coney index theory. All of this work has inspired interests in studying 3D vector field topology, with applications in fluid mechanics, magnetism, and oceanography.

The PI and collaborators have also studied the design of time-varying vector fields, with applications in entertainment and computer graphics. This represents the first time-varying vector field design system. In addition, they studied the design of symmetric tensor fields, i.e., tensors that are symmetric with respect to the transpose. Visualization of such tensors has long been studied in solid mechanics and medical imaging. The team of researchers expands existing research on tensor field design, which they apply to the design of street networks. Unlike traditional street modeling approaches that are based on mostly manual work which is time-consuming or grammars which lack global control, the PI and his collaborators use tensor fields to guide the global structures in the street network, and allow local fine-tuning through hierarchical street network editing. This leads to much improved ability to quickly generate a street network with both global and local control.

There are three directions that are beyond the original scope of the research.

First, the PI and his team of researchers provide theory and algorithms to the representation, analysis, design, and visualization of rotational symmetries, which have many applications in computer-generated art, texture and geometry synthesis, and mesh generation. They allow both manual design and automatic generation of rotational symmetry fields on surfaces. This effort has inspired much research in rotational symmetry analysis, design, and parameterization.

Second, the PI and his team of researchers provide the analysis and visualization of asymmetric tensor fields, i.e., tensors that are not symmetric with respect to the transpose. Such analysis has applications in seismology, fluid and solid mechanics, and chemistry. The analysis and visualization of the researchers provide new insights on the understanding of vector fields by studying their spatial derivatives, i.e., tensors. This provides an entirely new direction for both vector and tensor field visualization.
